thread.title: Iowa shows Northwestern what it takes to get to Big Ten title game
thread.title_full: Iowa shows Northwestern what it takes to get to Big Ten title game

author: Teddy Greenstein
title: Iowa shows Northwestern what it takes to get to Big Ten title game
text:
var ssaUrl = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https://' : 'http://') + 'pixel.sitescout.com/iap/0ea84626951144d2';new Image().src = ssaUrl;"/> College Football Iowa shows Northwestern what it takes to get to Big Ten title game Northwestern coach Pat Fitzgerald on 40-10 loss 
Northwestern coach Pat Fitzgerald on 40-10 loss to Iowa. 
Northwestern coach Pat Fitzgerald on 40-10 loss to Iowa. Teddy Greenstein Contact Reporter Of Iowa and Northwestern, one has a formula for winning. And it isn't the Wildcats. 
Quarterback C.J. Beathard is the player who "embodies" this Iowa team. Coach Kirk Ferentz said that, but Iowa fans already knew it. 
A backup on last year's snoozy 7-6 squad, Beathard represents the brains, moxie and — oh, yeah — fun of a 7-0 team that clobbered Northwestern 40-10 on Saturday at Ryan Field. 
And the play that embodied the blowout came in the fourth quarter on third-and-5. Beathard wanted to make a quick flip to Derrick Mitchell, but some Northwestern defenders were in the way. So Beathard waited and waited and waited some more until Mitchell finally got free. 
"It wasn't designed like that," Beathard said. 
Mitchell snatched Beathard's lob and went 23 yards. 
"Sometimes I think to myself: How does he make those plays?" receiver Tevaun Smith said. "I'm a fan out there too. He's a winner." 
All the action from Ryan Field. 
Ferentz joked about wanting to take credit for the play, knowing he couldn't. 
Then, alluding to how Beathard spent much of the game limping on what's believed to be a sore hip and groin, Ferentz dropped a reference only your grandfather would understand. 
"He was walking like Amos McCoy," Ferentz said to a room of blank faces. "You guys gotta look that up." 
That would be "Grandpa" Amos McCoy, whom Walter Brennan played on "The Real McCoys," a sitcom that aired from 1957 to '63. 
Bottom line on Beathard, Ferentz said: "That was just pure guts today on his part." 
One day, perhaps, redshirt freshman Northwestern quarterback Clayton Thorson will play with the same kind of savvy and efficiency. Maybe he will have receivers who can catch the ball. Maybe he will play for a coordinator who asks Justin Jackson to carry it more than 10 times, as he did Saturday. 
Whereas Iowa has its formula for victories — Saturday's rushing hero was third-stringer Akrum Wadley, who scored four times and churned out 204 yards — the Wildcats are a pass-happy team that can't pass. Their 43 attempts netted 147 yards, three sacks and an off-the-back-foot fling from Thorson that Desmond King easily intercepted. 
The Wildcats wore black 1995 throwback jerseys but did not resemble the group that went to the Rose Bowl. 
Remember when Iowa-Northwestern games were competitive? The Hawkeyes have outscored the Wildcats 88-17 the last two years. 
Saturday's "effort" was marked by dropped passes, dumb penalties, really dumb penalties, missed tackles, extremely curious play-calling and a flubbed/fumbled handoff. 
The motto of the '95 team was "Expect victory." 
The motto of this team should be "Expect more." 
If these Wildcats were good enough to drub a Stanford team that has dominated every other opponent on its schedule, then there's no excuse for being this bad in back-to-back games. 
Last week it was Michigan. Saturday it was an Iowa team that can book reservations for the Big Ten title game. 
Iowa has beaten Wisconsin and Illinois and has this cozy slate left: Maryland, at Indiana, Minnesota, Purdue, at Nebraska. 
"How good we are, I have no idea," Ferentz said. "But I do know this: This team plays extremely hard and has a lot of guts." 
Ferentz, wild and crazy guy that he is — look that up, kids — said he would extend the team's 24-hour rule for celebrating. 
"They have earned it," he said of a banged-up group whose shuffled offensive line helped the Hawkeyes to a 294-51 advantage in rushing yards. 
They also earned the crown jewel of an open date, which Beathard will use to get his legs back. 
"Couldn't be a better time for a bye week," Beathard said, "that's for sure."
